attributes.alt: Book cover for Happy Birthday, Moon by Frank Asch. The cover shows a teddy bear looking up at the full moon in the night sky.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to build background, engage children with the theme song, and introduce the vocabulary
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking,
Why did Bear go on a long trip?
Read for enjoyment and understanding, noticing vocabulary in context.
Show understanding of text read aloud; Share ideas and feelings.
Understand and use varied types of words; Understand and use a growing number of prepositions.
Remove word from a compound word.
Investigate, describe, and talk about objects that can be seen in the sky.
Challenge children to delete one word from a compound word.
Guide children to understand that some words are compound words.
What do we do during the day and at night?
What story would you like to read at bedtime? Why?
What do you do right after you wake up in the morning? Act it out.
What time do you go to bed at night? Can you write that number?
Draw or write about what your family is doing during the day.
Draw a picture of something you do during the day. Draw a picture of something you do at night.
Point to the letter that makes the first sound in
Build a playground for these stuffed animals.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to
Read closely to notice and talk about the Mind Builder.
Show understanding of text read aloud; Share ideas and feelings.
Show self-awareness in different/ multiple ways.
Identify unique characteristics in themselves, classmates, and children from other cultures.
Challenge children to act out a recently acquired ability and express their pride.
Guide children to understand that each new ability is a goal they reached through hard work.
What do we do during the day and at night?
Show me a story that takes place during the day.
Who works at night? Pretend you have a nighttime job. When will you sleep?
In our book today, the moon is always a circle. What other shapes of the moon could you draw?
What would happen if the day and the night got mixed up? Can you write or draw about that?
Use pictures in these magazines to make a collage of things people do in the daytime.
Show me the letter that makes the first sound in
Could you build a tower that reaches all the way to the moon? What materials would you use?

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share the comprehension skill
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking,
How is the moon in the story like the real moon?
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Respond to spoken language; Show understanding of spoken language.
Understand and use a growing number of prepositions.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Recognize and produce words with the same beginning sound.
Participate in prereading and reading-related activities.
Begin to experiment with end punctuation.
Describe what happens when the earth or the sky changes.
Challenge children to sort images into things that fit and things that don’t fit.
Guide children to understand that the word
can be used in a variety of ways.
What do we do during the day and at night?
Find a book with the moon in it.
Why do some grown-ups work during the night? Act out what they do.
Why is it dark at night and light during the day?
What is your favorite time of day? Why? Draw or write about why it is your favorite.
Draw a picture of something you use to protect yourself from the sun.
. Can you think of other words that begin with the same sound?
Build a moon rocket with these blocks.

attributes.alt: Big Chart of Big Ideas for Daytime Nighttime. On the left side is the word Daytime written on the sun. Below it are pictures that say: It's daytime in the mountains; It's daytime in the country; It's daytime in the city. On the right  side of the chart is the word Nighttime written over a starry sky. Below it are pictures that say: It's nighttime in the mountains; It's nighttime in the country; It's nighttime in the city.
Book cover for Happy Birthday, Moon by Frank Asch. The cover shows a teddy bear looking up at the full moon in the night sky.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to talk about what children learned about day and night and introduce vocabulary words
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts
Read closely to respond to the Concept Question,
What do we do during the day and at night?
Respond appropriately to spoken language; Show understanding of spoken language.
Understand and use category words; Make connections between words and real life.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Participate in prereading and reading-related activities.
Begin to experiment with end punctuation.
Describe what happens when the earth or the sky changes.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the relationship between plants and animals and their environments.
Challenge children to sort activity cards into two categories.
Guide children to understand that while most people sleep at night, some animals do not.
What do we do during the day and at night?
Which book is about the real world? Which is pretend?
Pretend you are going out to watch the moon tonight. What will you take with you?
Why do you think most people are busier during the day than at night?
Think of one word that rhymes with
Draw a picture of something you could use to help you see better at night.
Look at the first letter in
. Are they the same or different?
Use blocks to build a store where pretend shoppers can shop day and night.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to have children act out and describe what they do in the day and at night and to introduce vocabulary
What would you like to give the moon for his birthday?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and imagination.
Engage in conversations with a variety of partners, taking turns listening and speaking.
Show understanding of spoken language; Respond appropriately to spoken language.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Participate in prereading and reading-related activities.
Recognize and produce words that have the same beginning sound.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.
Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt:
What do you like about seeing the moon at night?
Save children’s writing to display next week.

. Can you think of another word that begins with that sound?
